author: app.com
title: Red Bank's 'Impossible Dream' season remembered
text:
MORE Bob Strangia still gets emotional when he talks about Red Bank Regional’s “Impossible Dream” season, choking back tears even though 40 years have passed.
“That was a true team, and it brought the entire community together,” said the Bucs' former head coach as he spoke from his home in Hobe Sound, Florida.
And it was the way the Bucs' perfect season ended that adds to the aura: winning their 28th straight game in the Central Jersey Group II final, defeating previously unbeaten Hightstown, 46-44, in what many still consider the greatest NJSIAA playoff game ever played.
When defensive back John Semliatschenko drove Hightstown quarterback Mike Radics out of bounds at the 1-yardline on a two-point conversion with just over two minutes to play to preserve the victory, it was the last of many memorable moments.
But what defined the team was the tightly woven fabric formed by the players and their families, many from diverse backgrounds, and from different parts of town and surrounding communities, to come together in an incredible show of unity.
“Off the field, we were friends and brothers,” said Jerry Agee of Marietta, , then a linebacker who averaged 12 tackles a game for the Bucs. “That translated into dinners at each other’s houses, breakfasts. It was more than just football, It was a very unique time frame in history. It didn’t matter if you were from the East Side of Red Bank or the West Side, everyone was well represented, including Shrewsbury and Little Silver.
